{{More citations needed|date=September 2009}} {{ infobox stadium | name = श्री शिवछत्रपती क्रिडानगरी
Shree Shiv Chhatrapati Sports Complex Stadium | image = | fullname = Shree Shiv Chhatrapati Sports Complex Stadium | location = [[Pune]], [[India]] | commissioner = [[Rajaram Mane I.A.S]] | coordinates = | broke_ground = 1992 | built = 1994 | opened = 1995 | renovated = 2007, 2008 | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | officer-In-charge = [[Rajaram Mane I.A.S]] | Officer-In-Charge = [[Rajaram Mane(Commissioner-IAS)]] | operator = [[Indian Olympic Association]] | surface = [[Grass]], [[concrete]] | construction_cost = | architect = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = | officer_in_charge = [[Rajaram Mane I.A.S]] | main_contractors = | former_names = | tenants = [[Air India FC|Air India]] (2011 – 2013)
[[Mumbai F.C.|Mumbai]] (2011 – 2013)
[[DSK Shivajians]] (present)
[[FC Pune City]] (2014 – present)
[[Bharat FC]] (2014 – 2015)
[[Puneri Paltan]] (2014 – present) | capacity = 11,900 (can be limited to 9,110 for ISL matches because of tarps/flags over the seatshttp://www.indiansuperleague.com/fc-pune-city/venue) | dimensions = 100.0 M x 68.0 M | scoreboard = }} The '''Shree Chhatrapati Shivaji Sports Complex''', [[Balewadi]], [[Mahalunge]], [[Pune]] is an Indian sports complex, which includes the '''Shree Shiv Chhatrapati Sports Complex Stadium'''. The complex is situated in Balewadi, Mahalunge Pune, about 14–15 km from Pune downtown and 4–5 km from [[Hinjawadi]], Pune. This complex was the venue for the [[2008 Commonwealth Youth Games]].{{cite news |title=Balewadi, Mahalunge sports complex gears up for Youth Games |url=http://www.expressindia.com/latest-news/balewadi-sports-complex-gears-up-for-youth-games/357137/ |work=[[Indian Express]] |date=4 September 2008 |accessdate=26 September 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120930070224/http://www.expressindia.com/latest-news/balewadi-sports-complex-gears-up-for-youth-games/357137/ |archivedate=30 September 2012 |df=dmy-all }} == History == This complex was built in 1994 for the [[National Games of India|National Games]] 1994, which were hosted by Pune. The [[2008 Commonwealth Youth Games]] were hosted here. In 2008 the World Junior Table Tennis Circuit was successfully held here. The [[2009 FIVB Men's Junior World Championship]] was held here. It was won by Brazil. The city is also the host of [[FIBA Asia Under-16 Championship for Women 2009]]. == Other games == ;American Football Beginning in fall 2012, the Athletics Stadium will undergo a [[retrofitting]] and become the host stadium for the [[Elite Football League of India]] and the home arena for the [[Pune Marathas (American football)|Pune Marathas]].https://sports.yahoo.com/nfl/news?slug=ycn-8919377 ;Rollball The [[2011 Rollball World Cup]] was held in this games village. This was the first [[Roll Ball World Cup|world cup]] of [[Roll Ball]]. [[Denmark national Rollball team|Denmark]] was the winner of this tournament. Also the 3rd Roll Ball World Cup in 2015 was organized here. ;Volleyball The [[2009 FIVB Men's Junior World Championship]] was held on 31 July 2009 to 9 August 2009. Host [[India men's national volleyball team|India]] ended 4th in this tournament. This Tournament was conducted in Badminton Hall and Boxing Arena. [[Brazil men's national volleyball team|Brazil]] won this championship. == Facilities == === Stadia === ==== Main Stadium ==== ==== Athletics ==== The Athletics stadium has a [[seating capacity]] of roughly 11,000 people at a time, Flood lights and an 8 lane track. ==== Football ==== [[File:Balewadi Athletics Stadiums Interior.jpg|thumb|India versus Vietnam football match in the Athletics Stadium]] The athletics stadium also hosts the [[I-League]] matches for [[Pune F.C.]]. It has also hosted matches for the [[India national football team]].http://www.thehardtackle.com/2010/india-v-vietnam-preview-and-pre-match-press-conference/ India played against [[Vietnam national football team|Vietnam]] in a friendly match over here. India played their first match in the [[Football at the 2012 Summer Olympics – Men's Asian Qualifiers Preliminary Round 1|2012 London Olympic Qualifiers (first round)]] against [[Myanmar national football team|Myanmar]]. India won it by a score 2-1. India drew with [[Qatar national football team|Qatar]] in the [[Football at the 2012 Summer Olympics – Men's Asian Qualifiers Preliminary Round 2|2012 London Olympic Qualifier (Second round)]] at the stadium by a score 1-1. Then during the [[2011 Indian Federation Cup]] the Balewadi Sports Complex co-hosted with the [[Salt Lake Stadium]] the Federation Cup group-stages. The [[Federation Cup (India)|Federation Cup]] is the second most important football competition in India.http://www.goal.com/en-india/match/65447/hal-bangalore-vs-salgaocar-sc/report This stadium will also be the host for upcoming [[Indian Super League]] for [[FC Pune City]] bought by [[Bollywood]] actor [[Hritik Roshan]]. ==== International football matches ==== {{Footballbox collapsible |round = |date = 8 October 2010 |time = |team1 = {{fb-rt|IND}} |score = 3 – 1 |report = [http://www.goal.com/en-india/match/50301/india-vs-vietnam/report Report] |team2 = {{fb|VIE}} |goals1 = [[Sunil Chhetri|Chhetri]] {{goal|25||48||72}} |goals2 = [[Vu Nhu Thanh|Thanh]] {{goal|62}} |location = [[Pune]] |stadium = Balewadi Sports Complex |attendance = |referee = [[Dinesh Nair]] ([[All India Football Federation|India]]) |stack = yes }} {{Footballbox collapsible |round = |date = 23 February 2011 |time = |team1 = [[India national under-23 football team|India u23]] {{flagicon|India}} |score = 2 – 1 |report = |team2 = {{flagicon|Myanmar}} Myanmar u23 |goals1 = [[Jeje Lalpekhlua|Lalpekhlua]]
[[Malsawmfela]] |goals2 = [[Mai Aih Naing]] |location = [[Pune]] |stadium = Balewadi Sports Complex |attendance = |referee = |stack = yes }} {{Footballbox collapsible |round = |date = 23 June 2011 |time = |team1 = [[India national under-23 football team|India u23]] {{flagicon|India}} |score = 1 – 1 |report = |team2 = {{flagicon|Qatar}} Qatar u23 |goals1 = [[Khalid Muftah]] o.g. |goals2 = [[Mohammed Elneel]] |location = [[Pune]] |stadium = Balewadi Sports Complex |attendance = |referee = |stack = yes }} {{Footballbox collapsible |round = |date = 31 August 2015 |time = 14:30 |team1 = [[India national football team|India]] {{flagicon|India}} |score = 0 – 0 |report = [http://www.goalnepal.com/news.php?id=24904 Report] |team2 = {{flagicon|Nepal}} Nepal |goals1 = |goals2 = |location = [[Pune]] |stadium = Balewadi Sports Complex |attendance = |referee = |stack = yes }} ==== Aquatics Centre ==== [[File:Shree Shiv Chhatrapati Sports Complex aquatic centre.jpeg|thumb|Aquatic centre]] This [[List of water sports|Aquatics]] centre contains two 50 x 25m swimming pools, with a [[seating capacity]] of 3500 people. This has changing room for players. Seating and lounges are for VIPs. For public usage the pool timings are 6:00 AM – 9:00AM and 3:00 PM – 6:00 PM from Monday to Saturday. ==== Badminton Hall ==== [[File:Shree Shiv Chhatrapati Sports Complex badminton arena.jpeg|thumb|Badminton hall]] The Badminton hall 6 competition courts and 4 warm-up courts, and has a [[seating capacity]] of 3800 people at a time. This hall is air condition and has wooden floor. It has changing room for players and sitting & lounges for VIPs.[http://www.cygpune2008.com/sports-venues/venue-badminton.php 2008 Commonwealth Youth Games (Badminton Venue) official site] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120405000924/http://www.cygpune2008.com/sports-venues/venue-badminton.php |date=5 April 2012 }} This venue is the home ground of [[Pune Pistons]] a franchise in [[Indian Badminton League|Indian Badminton League (IBL)]]. So far 3 [[Indian Badminton League|IBL]] matches have been played on this venue. ==== Basketball ==== The first edition of [[FIBA Asia Under-16 Championship for Women]] was played on this stadium from 30 November 2009 to 6 December 2009. Host [[India women's national basketball team|India]] finished on fifth position. It has been a host for the [[UBA Pro Basketball League]], India's prime professional basketball division.[https://www.sportskeeda.com/basketball/uba-bryan-seals-victory-punjab-steelers-over-chennai-slam UBA: Bryan seals victory for Punjab Steelers over Chennai Slam] Joe Williams (''sportskeeda''), 30 July 2016. Accessed 2 May 2017. ==== Boxing Arena ==== The Boxing arena has 3 rings, and 5 warm-up rings, with a [[seating capacity]] of 3500 peoples. This hall is air conditioned and has changing rooms for players. This arena is the host of 2011 [[World Series Boxing]]. ==== Shooting Range ==== The complex has 15 shooting ranges, with a [[seating capacity]] of 1500. The ranges are constructed according to ISSF rules world championship. Ranges: 50 m,25 m and 10 m are available [http://www.cygpune2008.com/sports-venues/venue-shooting-range.php 3rd Commonwealth Youth Games (Shooting Venue) official site] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120404235335/http://www.cygpune2008.com/sports-venues/venue-shooting-range.php |date=4 April 2012 }} ;Ranges: {| class="navbox wikitable" style="width:85%; text-align:left" ! Shooting Range ! Seating Capacity ! Firing points ! Notes |- | 10m Shooting Range | 425 | 80 | A/C |- | 25m Shooting Range | 425 | 50 | Non A/C |- | 50m Shooting Range | 700 | 80 | Non A/C |- | Combined Trap and Skee Shooting Range 1 | | | Non A/C |- | Combined Trap and Skee Shooting Range 2 | | | Non A/C |- | Combined Trap and Skee Shooting Range 3 | | | Non A/C |} ==== Table Tennis Hall ==== The hall, with a [[seating capacity]] of 1500 people, successfully held [[World Junior Table Tennis]] Circuit in September 2008. This has 4 competition tables and 4 warm up tables. This hall is air conditioned and has changing rooms for players. Seating and lounges are for VIPs. ==== Tennis Court ==== The Tennis courts feature one central court and four competition courts, with six warm-up courts. Centre court has a [[seating capacity]] of 4200 people. ==== Weightlifting Hall ==== This hall seats 3000 people. It hosted the 2009 commonwealth bench press championships. The most famous athlete to compete was Britain's strongest man Paddy the Pac man Jumelle. The hall is air conditioned and has one competition podium and 10 warm-up platforms. Seating and lounges are provided for VIPs. There is also a changing room for competitors. ==== Wrestling Hall ==== The Wrestling Hall, which is used by Kabaddi club [[Puneri Paltan]], has four rings, and six warm-up rings with a [[seating capacity]] of 4,400 people. This has seating and lounges for VIPs. This also has change room for players. This is an air conditioned hall. ==== Velodrome ==== [[File:Shree Shiv Chhatrapati Sports Complex velodrome.jpeg|thumb|400px|Velodrome]] {{main|Shree Shiv Chhatrapati Sports Complex velodrome}} The {{convert|333.33|m|ft|abbr=on|disp=or}} [[velodrome]] is outdoor and the surface is made of concrete. While it was a prime venue for the 3rd Nationals Games in the year 1993-94 it has never been a place for any major events thereafter, and was left unused. In 2014 it was announced that with a Rs 10 crore maintenance grant from the governments for the entire complex, the facelift of the velodrome had top priority. At that time the velodrome was in [[dilapidation|dilapidated]] state.[http://www.dnaindia.com/pune/report-finally-velodrome-at-balewadi-sports-complex-to-get-facelift-gets-grant-of-10-crore-1998112] === Games village === This is a non sporting venue at the sports city with 400 rooms, ranging between three and five star. === Other buildings === The other buildings are as follows: gym room, yoga room ;Cultural Centre: ;Fitness Centre: This centre has equipment to develop physical and physiological attributes. This hall is air condition hall and has provision for Yoga and Meditation. This has provision for sauna and chill water bath for recovery. ;Sports Science Centre: This centre has sauna and chill water bath. This has seven departments: # Central dope collection centre. # Department of bio-mechanics. # Department of nutrition and ergogenic aids. # Department of physiotherapy. # Department of Psychology. # Department of sports rehabilitation. # Human performance and evolution laboratory. == Teams == {| style="border: 1px solid #ADADAD; margin-bottom: 10px; padding-bottom: 5px;" |- style="background:#adadad; text-align:left;" ! style="width:150px;"| Club ! style="width:140px;"| Sport ! style="width:250px;"| League |- | [[FC Pune City]] | [[Association football|Football]] | [[Indian Super League]] |- | [[Pune F.C.]] | [[Association football|Football]] | [[I-League]] |- | [[Bharat FC]] | [[Association football|Football]] | [[I-League]] |- | [[Puneri Paltan]] | [[Kabbadi]] | [[Pro Kabaddi League]] |- | [[Pune Marathas (American football)|Pune Marathas]] | [[American Football]] | [[Elite Football League of India]] |} == Tournaments == ; Major Tournaments {| class="navbox wikitable" style="width:85%; text-align:left" ! ! Year ! Tournament |- | 1 | 1994 | [[National Games of India]] |- | 2 | 2008 | World Junior Table Tennis Circuit |- | 3 | 2008 (''[[2008 Commonwealth Youth Games|Details]]'') | [[Commonwealth Youth Games]] |- | 4 | 2009 (''[[2009 FIVB Men's Junior World Championship|Details]]'') | [[Men's Junior Volleyball World Championship]] |- | 5 | 2009 (''[[2009 FIBA Asia Under-16 Championship for Women|Details]]'') | [[FIBA Asia Under-16 Championship for Women]] |- | 6 | 2011 (''[[2011 Rollball World Cup|Details]]'') | [[2011 Rollball World Cup|Rollball World Cup]]. |- | 7 | 2011 | [[World Series Boxing]] |- | 8 | 2013 (''[[2013 Asian Athletics Championships|Details]]'') | [[Asian Athletics Championships]]. |- | 9 | 2014 (''[[2014 Pro Kabaddi League|Details]]'') | [[Pro Kabaddi League]] |- | 10 | 2014 (''[[2011 Rollball World Cup|Details]]'') | [[Rollball]] |- |} ;Professional Leagues and Cups {| class="navbox wikitable" style="width:85%; text-align:left" ! ! Sport ! Team ! League ! Seasons ! Matches Played |- | 1 | [[American Football]] | [[Pune Marathas (American football)|Pune Marathas]] | [[Elite Football League of India]] | ''[[2012-13 Elite Football League of India|2012-13]]'' | 0 |- | 2 | [[Badminton]] | [[Pune Pistons]] | [[Indian Badminton League]] | ''[[2013 Indian Badminton League|2013]]'' | 3 |- | 3 | [[Association Football|Football]] | [[FC Pune City]] | [[Indian Super League]] | 2014,2015 with Semi-Finals. | 15 |- | 4 | [[Association Football|Football]] | [[Pune F.C.|Pune]] | [[I-League]] | ''[[2009–10 I-League|2009–10]], [[2010–11 I-League|2010-11]], [[2011–12 I-League|2011–12]], [[2012–13 I-League|2012–13]], [[2013–14 I-League|2013–14]]'' | 89 |- | 5 | [[Association Football|Football]] | Group A and Group B | [[Federation Cup (India)|Indian Federation Cup]] | ''[[2011 Indian Federation Cup|2011]]'' | 7 |- | 6 | [[Kabaddi]] | [[Puneri Paltan]] | [[Pro Kabaddi League]] | [[2014 Pro Kabaddi League|2014]], ''[[2015 Pro Kabaddi League|2015]]'' | 7 |- |} == Other uses == === Filmset === Several scenes for the 2016 film [[Dangal (film)|Dangal]] were filmed at this sports complex in December 2015. The film is about two Indian daughters who won the gold and silver medal in wrestling at the [[2010 Commonwealth Games]]. == References == {{commons category|Shree Shiv Chhatrapati Sports Complex}} {{reflist}} {{s-start}} {{succession box | title=[[Asian Athletics Championships]]

[[Kasarani]]| }} {{s-end}} {{Indian Super League stadiums}} {{Pune topics}} {{Football stadiums in India}} {{coord|18.574745|73.760984|display=t|type:landmark}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2010}} [[Category:Sports venues in Pune]] [[Category:Sports venues in Maharashtra]] [[Category:Shooting ranges in India]] [[Category:Sport in Pune]] [[Category:Football venues in Pune]] [[Category:Kabaddi venues in India]] [[Category:Football venues in India]] [[Category:Basketball venues in India]] [[Category:Volleyball venues in India]] [[Category:Multi-purpose stadiums in India]] [[Category:1993 establishments in India]] [[Category:Field hockey venues in India]] [[Category:Monuments and memorials to Shivaji]] [[Category:Football venues in Maharashtra]] [[Category:Sports complexes]] [[Category:American football venues]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1993]]

[[AS Roma|Roma]] (1940–1953) | seating_capacity = 47,300 | dimensions = 105 m × 68 m }} The '''Stadio Nazionale del PNF''' (National Stadium of the [[National Fascist Party]]) was a [[multi-purpose stadium]] in [[Rome]], [[Italy]]. It hosted three of the 17 matches of the [[1934 FIFA World Cup]], including the final between hosts [[Italy national football team|Italy]] and [[Czechoslovakia national football team|Czechoslovakia]] on 10 June 1934. The Stadio Nazionale was constructed in 1911, and was renovated in 1928 for the Italy - Hungary international match.{{cite news|url=http://ricerca.repubblica.it/repubblica/archivio/repubblica/1988/02/17/dal-1911-ad-oggi-tutti-gli-stadi.html|title=DAL 1911 AD OGGI TUTTI GLI STADI DI ROMA|date=17 February 1988|work=[[La Repubblica]]|language=Italian|accessdate=19 April 2015}} The stadium closed in 1953 and was replaced by the [[Stadio Flaminio]] in 1957. == References == {{reflist}} {{s-start}} {{succession box | title=[[FIFA World Cup]]
Final Venue| before=[[Estadio Centenario]]
[[Montevideo]]| after=[[Stade Olympique de Colombes]]
[[Paris]]| years=[[1934 FIFA World Cup|1934]] }} {{s-end}} {{FIFA World Cup Final stadiums}} {{1934 FIFA World Cup stadiums}} {{S.S. Lazio}} {{A.S. page.title: Tajikistan at the 2013 World Championships in Athletics

{{Infobox country at games | IAAF = TJK | fedname = Athletics Federation of the Republic of Tajikistan | year = 2013 | games = World Championships in Athletics | location = [[Moscow]] | competitors = 17 | gold = 0 | silver = 0 | bronze = 0 | rank = | previous = [[Tajikistan at the 2011 World Championships in Athletics|2011]] | next = [[Tajikistan at the 2015 World Championships in Athletics|2015]] | website = }} '''[[Tajikistan]]''' competed at the '''[[2013 World Championships in Athletics]]''' in [[Moscow]], [[Russia]], from 10–18 August 2013. {{multiple issues| {{Underlinked|date=December 2013}} {{Unreferenced|date=May 2013}} {{orphan|date=May 2010}} }}
A '''wallflip''' is a [[stunt]] involving a [[Flip (acrobatic)|backflip]] from a wall. This is commonly used in urban [[acrobatics]] displays. A wallflip involves running up to a wall (or other vertical or near-vertical surface) and placing your foot on this surface. You must then push off with enough [[force]] to complete a three-quarter rotation and land back on your feet.
== Variations == '''Two-Step Wallflip'''
This is identical to the wallflip. However to perform it one will take an extra step up the wall for a total of two steps. This trick can be done with either foot being used first; however for beginners, the first step will consist of the less dominant foot so when the second step is taken the user will have more force to push off and complete the flip.
'''Three-Step Wallflip'''
Also identical to the wallflip, however consisting of three steps taken up the wall instead of one. Once again this can be performed using any combination of foot placement; however for beginners the more dominant leg will take the first step, followed by the less dominant. This will then allow the dominant leg to take the third and final step, ensuring the completion of the flip.
'''Four-Step Wallflip'''
Just as the name implies, this is a wallflip with four steps. This trick is very uncommon and difficult. It is rarely done outside of the gym although a Four-Step Wallflip on a "real" urban wall is not unheard of. However, less than a dozen tricksters have ever landed it outside of the gym.{{Citation needed|date=December 2007}}
'''Wallflip Twist'''
This stunt starts out similar to the wallflip in the effect that the performer runs up to a vertical surface and places their foot on this surface. It differs, however, because after one places their foot on the vertical surface they must twist their upper body to do a half rotation while also pushing off to do the flip. This will result in the user landing facing away from the wall instead of towards the wall.
'''Wall to wall flip'''
The wall to wall flip uses more than one surface when being performed. This trick will start by running up to one surface then placing either foot on this surface. The user will then jump or run to the second surface (commonly used on a 90 degree angle corner in which case the first surface is one wall and the second surface is the intersecting wall) and push with their opposite foot to complete the rotation. This trick can be done with any combination of steps or directions.
'''Wallflip Full Twist'''
This stunt starts out like a wallflip by the performer running to a wall and placing their foot on the wall. Then it changes and requires the performer to push up and still do a back somersault but also do a 360 degree rotation during the backwards rotation. Once both rotations are complete, the performer lands facing the wall again.
== Troubleshooting == The wallflip is an easier and simple trick because it consists of only a three quarter rotation instead of a full rotation. The extra quarter is subtracted because the trick starts from the vertical surface used. To perform this trick correctly one must push both away from the wall and upwards from the wall. The force pushing away from the wall is so that the user does not come into contact with the surface during the trick, such as hitting their head on the surface while they are rotating. The upwards force gives the trick height and will also force rotation to ensure a proper landing.
To overcome the fear of not making the full rotation, a [[Spotting (climbing)|spotter]] or two spotters may be used. They should stand to the side of the user, and when the user is horizontal with their back facing the floor, the spotters may give them extra rotation and height by pushing their back upwards (this is similar to the way in which spotters can be used when learning a backtuck).
==References== {{Reflist}}

{{Infobox sports team | logo = | pixels = | full_name = Zob Ahan Cultural and Sport Club | nicknames = Greens | founded = 6 July 1969; 45 years ago | city = [[Isfahan]], [[Iran]] | colors = {{color box|green}} {{color box|white}} Green and White | president = [[Saeed Azari]] | website = http://zobahanclub.com/ }}
'''Zob Ahan Cultural and Sport Club''' is an [[Iran]]ian [[multisport club]] based in [[Isfahan]], [[Iran]]. The club was founded in 1969. It is sponsored by the ''[[Isfahan Steel Company]]'', which also goes by the name Zob Ahan.
Zob Ahan club is most known for its [[Zob Ahan Isfahan FC|football]] and [[Zob Ahan Isfahan BC|basketball]] teams.
==Football== {{main|Zob Ahan Isfahan FC}} [[Zob Ahan F.C.|Zob Ahan Football Club]] is an Iranian football team competing in the [[Iran Pro League]]. The team plays at [[Fooladshahr Stadium]] in [[Fooladshahr]]. Since the inception of the new Iran Pro League in 2001, Zob Ahan has never been relegated to the [[Azadegan League]]. Zob Ahan have won the [[Hazfi Cup]] on two occasions. In 2010 Zob Ahan made it to the [[2010 AFC Champions League Final]] against [[Seongnam FC]], they lost 3-1.
==Basketball== {{main|Zob Ahan Isfahan BC}} [[Zob Ahan Isfahan BC|Zob Ahan Basketball Club]] is an Iranian professional [[basketball]] club located in [[Isfahan]], [[Iran]]. They are one of the most successful clubs in the history of the [[Iranian Basketball Super League]] winning the championship nine times.
==Volleyball== Zob Ahan is not active anymore in men's volleyball. Zob Ahan women's volleyball team is the current Iranian league champion.
===Honors=== *'''[[Iranian Volleyball Super League|Iranian Super League]]''' :Runners-up (2): [[Iranian Volleyball Super League 1996–97|1997]], [[Iranian Volleyball Super League 1997–98|1998]] :Third place (3): 1993, 1996, [[Iranian Volleyball Super League 1998–99|1999]]
==Other teams== *[[Olympic weightlifting|Weightlifting]] *[[Team handball|Handball]] *[[Table tennis]] *[[Swimming (sport)|Swimming]] *[[Athletics (sport)|Athletics]] *[[Water polo]]
